metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: describe the limitation of classical mechanics when considering motion approaching the speed of light

absolute_space_time.name: Absolute Space and Time
absolute_space_time.formula: Classical: space and time are fixed
absolute_space_time.correct: Classical physics assumes space and time are absolute, meaning all observers agree on measurements of length and time regardless of motion.

relative to the observer.error: That is the special relativity view, not classical physics.
relative to the observer.fix: Classical physics assumes measurements are universal. Special relativity says they depend on the observer.
relative to the observer.action: Compare: classical says everyone measures the same time. Relativity says moving observers disagree.

depend on velocity.error: In classical physics, space and time do not depend on velocity.
depend on velocity.fix: Classical assumes fixed space and time. Only special relativity introduces velocity-dependent measurements.
depend on velocity.action: Ask: does classical physics predict time dilation? No. That is why classical has limitations.

can be stretched or compressed.error: Stretching and compressing is length contraction and time dilation, which are relativistic effects.
can be stretched or compressed.fix: Classical physics treats space and time as rigid and unchanging.
can be stretched or compressed.action: Length contraction and time dilation are predictions of special relativity, not classical mechanics.

persistent.gap: You are confusing classical and relativistic assumptions about space and time.
persistent.action: Make a comparison table: classical assumes absolute space and time. Relativity assumes they are relative.

classical_validity.name: Classical Mechanics Validity Range
classical_validity.correct: Classical mechanics gives accurate predictions only at speeds much less than the speed of light. At high speeds, it fails.

at all speeds.error: Classical mechanics breaks down at relativistic speeds.
at all speeds.fix: Classical works well for everyday speeds but fails as v approaches c.
at all speeds.action: Calculate classical KE for an electron at 0.99c. Compare to relativistic KE. Huge difference.

only at the speed of light.error: Classical starts failing well before reaching c.
only at the speed of light.fix: Deviations become significant at around 10% of c and grow larger as speed increases.
only at the speed of light.action: At 0.1c, classical KE is off by about 1%. At 0.9c, it is off by a factor of 3.

above the speed of light.error: Nothing with mass can reach or exceed c. Classical fails before that point.
above the speed of light.fix: Classical mechanics fails at high fractions of c. Special relativity prevents v from ever reaching c.
above the speed of light.action: The question is not about exceeding c. It is about approaching c.

persistent.gap: You do not understand where classical mechanics becomes inaccurate.
persistent.action: Research: at what fraction of c does classical KE differ from relativistic KE by 10%? About 0.4c.

speed_of_light_constancy.name: Speed of Light Constancy
speed_of_light_constancy.correct: Special relativity states that all observers measure the same speed of light, regardless of their motion or the motion of the source.

depends on the observer's speed.error: That is the classical prediction, which is wrong.
depends on the observer's speed.fix: Experiments show c is constant for all observers. This is Einstein's second postulate.
depends on the observer's speed.action: Michelson-Morley expected to measure different light speeds. They found c was constant.

depends on the source's speed.error: The speed of light does not depend on source motion.
depends on the source's speed.fix: Unlike sound, light speed is independent of source velocity.
depends on the source's speed.action: A star moving toward Earth emits light at c, not c plus the star's velocity.

can be exceeded by fast objects.error: Nothing with mass can reach or exceed c.
can be exceeded by fast objects.fix: c is a universal speed limit for objects with mass.
can be exceeded by fast objects.action: As v approaches c, the energy required to accelerate further approaches infinity.

persistent.gap: You do not grasp the constancy of the speed of light.
persistent.action: Review Einstein's second postulate: the speed of light is constant for all inertial observers.

classical_velocity_addition.name: Classical Velocity Addition
classical_velocity_addition.correct: Classical physics predicts that relative velocities simply add linearly. This fails at high speeds.

velocities cannot be added.error: Velocities can be added, but the formula changes at high speeds.
velocities cannot be added.fix: Classical addition works at low speeds. At high speeds, relativistic addition is needed.
velocities cannot be added.action: At everyday speeds, v₁ + v₂ is accurate. At 0.5c + 0.5c, classical predicts c, but reality gives 0.8c.

velocities add nonlinearly at all speeds.error: At low speeds, linear addition is an excellent approximation.
velocities add nonlinearly at all speeds.fix: The nonlinear relativistic formula reduces to linear addition when v << c.
velocities add nonlinearly at all speeds.action: For a car at 30 m/s passing another at 20 m/s, v₁ + v₂ works perfectly.

velocities multiply rather than add.error: Velocities are combined through addition, not multiplication.
velocities multiply rather than add.fix: Classical uses addition: v_rel = v₁ + v₂. Relativistic formula is more complex but still involves addition.
velocities multiply rather than add.action: Check the relativistic velocity addition formula. It has addition in the numerator.

persistent.gap: You are confused about how velocities combine.
persistent.action: Learn both formulas: classical v_rel = v₁ + v₂, relativistic v_rel = (v₁ + v₂)/(1 + v₁v₂/c²).

relativistic_velocity_prediction.name: Relativistic Velocity Predictions
relativistic_velocity_prediction.correct: Special relativity predicts that relative speeds never exceed c, even when two objects approach each other at high speeds.

can exceed c.error: Relative speeds can never exceed c according to special relativity.
can exceed c.fix: The relativistic formula ensures v_rel is always less than c when v₁ and v₂ are less than c.
can exceed c.action: Calculate: if v₁ = v₂ = 0.6c, classical gives 1.2c, but relativistic gives 0.88c.

always equals c.error: Relative speed equals c only when one object is light.
always equals c.fix: For massive objects, relative speed is always less than c.
always equals c.action: Two rockets at 0.5c each have relative speed 0.8c, not c.

equals zero when both move at c.error: Massive objects cannot move at c.
equals zero when both move at c.fix: Only massless particles like photons travel at c. Massive objects always travel slower.
equals zero when both move at c.action: The premise is impossible. Focus on objects at fractions of c.

persistent.gap: You do not understand relativistic velocity addition.
persistent.action: Practice: calculate relative velocity for two objects at 0.9c approaching each other. Answer is 0.994c, not 1.8c.

classical_kinetic_energy.name: Classical Kinetic Energy Formula
classical_kinetic_energy.correct: Classical kinetic energy is KE = ½mv². This formula underestimates the true energy at high speeds.

KE = mv².error: Missing the factor of one half.
KE = mv².fix: Classical KE = ½mv², derived from work-energy theorem.
KE = mv².action: The ½ comes from integrating F·dx = ma·dx = m(dv/dt)·v·dt.

KE = ½mv.fix: KE = ½mv². Energy scales with v², not v.
KE = ½mv.action: Double the speed, quadruple the KE. That requires v².

KE = mc².error: That is rest mass energy, not kinetic energy.
KE = mc².fix: mc² is rest energy. KE is additional energy from motion.
KE = mc².action: E₀ = mc² is energy at rest. KE is energy due to motion.

persistent.gap: You do not know the classical kinetic energy formula.
persistent.action: Memorise: KE = ½mv². Then learn: relativistic KE = (γ - 1)mc².

relativistic_kinetic_energy.name: Relativistic Kinetic Energy
relativistic_kinetic_energy.correct: Relativistic kinetic energy is KE = (γ - 1)mc², which is always greater than classical KE at high speeds.

less than classical KE.error: Relativistic KE is greater, not less.
less than classical KE.fix: As γ > 1 always, and γ increases with speed, relativistic KE exceeds classical KE.
less than classical KE.action: At 0.9c, γ ≈ 2.3, so KE = 1.3mc². Classical gives 0.405mc². Big difference.

equal to classical KE.error: They are equal only at v = 0, where both are zero.
equal to classical KE.fix: For any v > 0, relativistic KE exceeds classical KE, with the gap growing as v increases.
equal to classical KE.action: Plot both: they diverge significantly above 0.1c.

always equals mc².error: mc² is rest energy, not kinetic energy.
always equals mc².fix: KE = (γ - 1)mc² varies with speed. mc² is constant rest energy.
always equals mc².action: At v = 0, γ = 1, so KE = 0. As v approaches c, KE approaches infinity.

persistent.gap: You are confusing rest energy with kinetic energy.
persistent.action: Review: E_total = γmc², E_rest = mc², KE = (γ - 1)mc². Practice calculating each.

lorentz_factor_behaviour.name: Lorentz Factor Behaviour
lorentz_factor_behaviour.correct: The Lorentz factor γ equals 1 at rest, increases gradually at low speeds, and increases dramatically as v approaches c.

decreases as speed increases.error: γ increases with speed, not decreases.
decreases as speed increases.fix: As v increases, v²/c² increases, so √(1 - v²/c²) decreases, making γ larger.

equals zero at rest.action: Substitute v = 0 into the formula. You get γ = 1.

is always equal to 1.fix: γ increases with speed. At 0.9c, γ ≈ 2.3.
is always equal to 1.action: Calculate γ for different speeds. It only equals 1 at rest.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how the Lorentz factor behaves with speed.
persistent.action: Make a table: v/c = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9, 0.99. Calculate γ for each. Notice the rapid increase near c.

inertial_reference_frame.name: Inertial Reference Frame
inertial_reference_frame.correct: An inertial reference frame is one that is not accelerating. It moves at constant velocity or is at rest.

any frame of reference.fix: Only constant-velocity frames are inertial. Accelerating frames are non-inertial.
any frame of reference.action: A car turning a corner is non-inertial. A car moving straight at constant speed is inertial.

only frames at rest.error: Constant velocity frames are also inertial.
only frames at rest.fix: Both stationary and constant-velocity frames are inertial.
only frames at rest.action: A train at constant speed is inertial, even though it is moving.

frames moving at the speed of light.error: No massive object can move at c, and reference frames are attached to observers.
frames moving at the speed of light.fix: Inertial frames move at v < c. Light does not define a reference frame.
frames moving at the speed of light.action: Reference frames are for observers with mass. Photons do not have rest frames.

persistent.gap: You do not understand inertial reference frames.
persistent.action: Key test: can you distinguish this frame from a stationary one without looking outside? If no, it is inertial.

measurement_disagreement.name: Observer Disagreement in Relativity
measurement_disagreement.formula: t, L depend on reference frame
measurement_disagreement.correct: In special relativity, observers in relative motion disagree on time intervals and lengths. In classical physics, they agree.

classical physics predicts disagreement.error: Classical physics assumes universal agreement on measurements.
classical physics predicts disagreement.fix: Disagreement on time and length is a relativistic prediction, not classical.
classical physics predicts disagreement.action: Classical physics: all clocks tick the same. Relativity: moving clocks tick slower.

only length is different.error: Both time and length change between frames.
only length is different.fix: Moving observers measure dilated time and contracted length.
only length is different.action: Time dilation: t = γt₀. Length contraction: L = L₀/γ. Both change.

measurements are random.fix: The Lorentz transformations precisely relate measurements in different frames.
measurements are random.action: Nothing is random. Given v and measurements in one frame, you can calculate them in another.

persistent.gap: You confuse classical and relativistic predictions about measurements.
persistent.action: Key difference: classical says all observers agree. Relativity says they disagree in predictable ways.

approaching_c_behaviour.name: Behaviour as Speed Approaches c
approaching_c_behaviour.correct: As speed approaches c, the Lorentz factor approaches infinity, requiring infinite energy for further acceleration.

γ approaches zero.error: γ increases without bound as v approaches c.
γ approaches zero.fix: At v = 0.99c, γ ≈ 7. At v = 0.999c, γ ≈ 22. γ grows toward infinity.
γ approaches zero.action: Calculate γ for v = 0.9c, 0.99c, 0.999c. Watch it grow.

γ approaches 1.error: γ = 1 only at v = 0. It increases with speed.
γ approaches 1.fix: γ = 1 is the minimum value, occurring at rest.
γ approaches 1.action: γ starts at 1 and increases. It cannot approach 1 from above.

γ approaches c.error: γ is dimensionless. It cannot equal a speed.
γ approaches c.fix: γ is a unitless factor. It approaches infinity, not any finite value.
γ approaches c.action: Check units: γ = 1/√(1 - v²/c²) has no units.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the behaviour of γ near c.
persistent.action: Plot γ vs v/c. Notice the asymptote at v = c where γ → ∞.

energy_speed_limit.name: Energy and the Speed Limit
energy_speed_limit.correct: As speed approaches c, total energy approaches infinity. This is why massive objects cannot reach c.

energy becomes zero at c.fix: More speed requires more energy. Near c, the energy requirement becomes infinite.

energy stays constant.fix: Kinetic energy is (γ - 1)mc², which increases as v increases.
energy stays constant.action: Compare energies at 0.1c and 0.9c. The second is much higher.

only rest energy matters.error: Both rest energy and kinetic energy contribute to total energy.
only rest energy matters.action: At high speeds, kinetic energy dominates total energy.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why c is a speed limit.
persistent.action: Key insight: infinite energy is needed to reach c. No finite energy source can provide this.

classical_assumptions.title: Classical Physics Assumptions
classical_assumptions.instructions: Complete the statements about classical physics assumptions.

sentences.text: Classical physics assumes that space and time are {{d1}}, meaning that all observers should agree on measurements of {{d2}} and {{d3}} regardless of their motion.

d1.tooltip: Classical physics treats space and time as fixed and universal.

d2.tooltip: What spatial measurement would observers compare?

d3.tooltip: What temporal measurement would observers compare?

sentences.text: At low speeds, classical assumptions are {{d4}} approximations, but they become inaccurate as speeds approach the {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Do classical predictions work well at everyday speeds?

d5.tooltip: What speed defines the limit of classical mechanics?

sentences.text: Special relativity shows that measurements of space and time {{d6}} on the observer's frame of reference, contradicting the classical assumption of {{d7}} measurements.

d6.tooltip: Do different observers get the same measurements in relativity?

d7.tooltip: Classical physics assumed measurements were the same for everyone.

relativistic_regime.title: The Relativistic Regime
relativistic_regime.instructions: Complete the statements about when relativistic effects become important.

sentences.text: An inertial reference frame is one that is {{d1}}, meaning it moves at {{d2}} or remains at rest.

d2.tooltip: What type of motion is allowed in an inertial frame?

sentences.text: Einstein's second postulate states that the speed of light has the same value of {{d3}} for {{d4}} observers, regardless of their motion.

d3.tooltip: What is the speed of light in a vacuum?

d4.tooltip: Which observers measure the same speed of light?

sentences.text: The Lorentz factor γ equals {{d5}} when an object is at rest and {{d6}} as speed approaches c.

d6.tooltip: What happens to γ as v gets closer to c?

velocity_addition.title: Velocity Addition
velocity_addition.instructions: Complete the statements comparing classical and relativistic velocity addition.

sentences.text: Classical physics predicts that velocities add {{d1}}, so two objects approaching each other at 0.6c each would have a relative speed of {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: How does classical physics combine velocities?

sentences.text: The classical prediction of 1.2c violates the principle that nothing can travel {{d3}} than the speed of light, revealing a fundamental {{d4}} of classical mechanics.

d3.tooltip: c is the universal speed limit.

d4.tooltip: Classical mechanics fails at high speeds.

sentences.text: Special relativity predicts that the same two objects would have a relative speed of {{d5}}, which is {{d6}} than c.

d5.tooltip: Use the relativistic velocity addition formula.

d6.tooltip: Relativistic addition always gives results less than c.

energy_comparison.title: Kinetic Energy Comparison
energy_comparison.instructions: Complete the statements comparing classical and relativistic kinetic energy.

sentences.text: Classical kinetic energy is calculated using KE = {{d1}}, which gives accurate results at {{d2}} speeds.

d1.tooltip: What is the classical kinetic energy formula?

d2.tooltip: When is the classical formula accurate?

sentences.text: Relativistic kinetic energy is KE = {{d3}}, which is always {{d4}} than the classical prediction at high speeds.

d3.tooltip: What is the relativistic kinetic energy formula?

d4.tooltip: How does relativistic KE compare to classical KE?

sentences.text: As speed approaches c, the energy required for further acceleration approaches {{d5}}, which is why no object with {{d6}} can reach the speed of light.

d5.tooltip: What happens to energy requirements near c?

d6.tooltip: What property prevents objects from reaching c?

classical_assumptions.title: Applying Classical Assumptions
classical_assumptions.instructions: Apply your understanding of classical physics assumptions to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A scientist measures the length of a moving train from the platform. According to classical physics, the train's length would be {{d1}} as measured by a passenger inside the train, but special relativity predicts the platform observer measures a {{d2}} length.

d1.tooltip: Classical physics assumes length is absolute.

d2.tooltip: Relativity predicts length contraction for moving objects.

sentences.text: Two synchronised clocks are separated, with one placed on a fast-moving spacecraft. Classical physics predicts both clocks show {{d3}} time, while special relativity predicts the moving clock runs {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Classical physics assumes time is universal.

d4.tooltip: Time dilation means moving clocks tick slower.

sentences.text: The deviation between classical and relativistic predictions is negligible at speeds like 100 km/h because v/c is approximately {{d5}}, making γ approximately {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: 100 km/h is about 28 m/s. Compare to c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s.

d6.tooltip: When v << c, γ is very close to 1.

relativistic_regime.title: Identifying Relativistic Conditions
relativistic_regime.instructions: Identify when relativistic effects become significant.

sentences.text: A particle accelerator brings electrons to 0.99c. At this speed, the Lorentz factor γ is approximately {{d1}}, indicating that relativistic effects are {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: γ = 7 is far from 1, so classical physics fails badly.

sentences.text: Particle accelerators must be designed using {{d3}} mechanics because classical predictions would underestimate the {{d4}} needed to reach target speeds.

d3.tooltip: Which mechanics applies at speeds near c?

d4.tooltip: What resource does classical physics underestimate?

sentences.text: GPS satellites orbit at high speeds and their clocks {{d5}} compared to Earth clocks due to time dilation, requiring corrections based on {{d6}} theory.

d5.tooltip: Moving clocks run slow relative to stationary ones.

velocity_addition.title: Velocity Addition Scenarios
velocity_addition.instructions: Apply velocity addition formulas to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: A rocket travelling at 0.5c fires a probe forward at 0.5c relative to the rocket. Classical physics predicts the probe's speed relative to Earth is {{d1}}, but the actual speed is {{d2}}.
The Michelson-Morley experiment showed that the speed of light is {{d3}} regardless of Earth's motion, which {{d4}} the classical prediction that light speed should vary with observer motion.

d3.tooltip: What did Michelson-Morley find about light speed?

d4.tooltip: Did the experiment agree with classical predictions?

sentences.text: If classical velocity addition were correct, a spacecraft turning on its headlights while moving at 0.5c would emit light at {{d5}} relative to Earth, but experiments confirm light always travels at {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: Light always travels at c for all observers.

energy_comparison.title: Energy at High Speeds
energy_comparison.instructions: Compare energy predictions at relativistic speeds.

sentences.text: At 0.9c, the classical KE formula gives KE = 0.405mc², while the relativistic formula gives KE = {{d1}}, showing classical physics {{d2}} the actual energy.

d1.tooltip: γ at 0.9c is about 2.29, so KE = (2.29-1)mc² = 1.29mc².

d2.tooltip: Classical KE is always less than relativistic KE at high speeds.

sentences.text: The ratio of relativistic to classical KE at 0.9c is approximately {{d3}}, demonstrating that classical mechanics {{d4}} describes motion at this speed.

d4.tooltip: A factor of 3 error means classical fails badly.

sentences.text: A proton at relativistic speed in an accelerator has kinetic energy {{d5}} than classical physics predicts, which is why accelerator designs must account for {{d6}} effects.

d6.tooltip: Which effects must accelerator designs consider?

classical_assumptions.title: Mastering Classical Limitations
classical_assumptions.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of classical physics limitations.

sentences.text: The fundamental incompatibility between classical mechanics and observations at high speeds arises because classical physics assumes {{d1}} cannot depend on {{d2}}, while experiments show they do.

d1.tooltip: What does classical physics assume is absolute?

d2.tooltip: What factor causes measurements to differ in relativity?

sentences.text: A common misconception is that classical mechanics fails only exactly at c, but significant deviations occur at {{d3}} of c, where γ differs noticeably from {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Classical mechanics fails well before reaching c.

d4.tooltip: When is γ close to its rest value?

sentences.text: The transition from classical to relativistic behaviour is {{d5}}, not abrupt, with deviations growing as the ratio {{d6}} increases.

relativistic_regime.title: Deep Understanding of Relativity
relativistic_regime.instructions: Demonstrate comprehensive understanding of relativistic physics.

sentences.text: Einstein's postulates resolve the contradiction between Maxwell's equations and classical mechanics by showing that {{d1}} is invariant, while {{d2}} are frame-dependent.

d1.tooltip: What is constant for all observers?

sentences.text: The Lorentz factor can be written as γ = 1/√(1 - v²/c²), which shows that γ becomes {{d3}} as v²/c² approaches {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What happens when the denominator approaches zero?

d4.tooltip: At v = c, what is v²/c²?

sentences.text: The impossibility of reaching c for massive objects follows mathematically from the fact that {{d5}} would require {{d6}} energy input.

d6.tooltip: How much energy would be needed to reach c?

velocity_addition.title: Synthesis of Velocity Concepts
velocity_addition.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of velocity in relativity.

sentences.text: The relativistic velocity addition formula v = (v₁ + v₂)/(1 + v₁v₂/c²) reduces to the classical formula v = v₁ + v₂ when the product v₁v₂ is {{d1}} compared to {{d2}}.
When a light beam is emitted from a moving source, the relativistic formula correctly predicts that all observers measure the light's speed as {{d3}}, demonstrating that c is {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What speed do all observers measure for light?

d4.tooltip: c does not change between reference frames.

sentences.text: The failure of classical velocity addition reveals that our intuition, developed at {{d5}} speeds, does not apply to motion approaching {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: Near what speed does classical intuition fail?

energy_comparison.title: Complete Energy Understanding
energy_comparison.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of energy concepts in relativity.

sentences.text: The total energy of a moving object E = γmc² includes both {{d1}} energy (mc²) and {{d2}} energy ((γ-1)mc²), with the latter dominating at high speeds.

d1.tooltip: mc² is what type of energy?

sentences.text: The ratio of relativistic to classical kinetic energy approaches {{d3}} as speed increases, explaining why particle accelerators need far more energy than {{d4}} physics would predict.

d3.tooltip: How does the ratio behave as v approaches c?

d4.tooltip: Which physics underestimates the energy needed?

sentences.text: At the Large Hadron Collider, protons reach 0.999999991c, where γ ≈ 7500. Classical physics would predict KE = {{d5}}, but the actual KE is approximately {{d6}}.
